Hi!
Here with I have attached two files. There is a simple application
"JU=
til.java", which I have written.This makes use of the reflection
API's to g=
enerate the skeleton of the test cases for the classes which
are already wr=
itten. It generates the two test cases for each method in
the class with th=
e suffix 'Good' and 'Bad'. we are using 'Good' method
for the positive test=
 case and 'Bad' for the negative test case. So if
you want to add any other=
 test cases, then you got to add it manually.

The usage goes like this, 
W=
hich takes the 3 arguments as follows,

commond: java JUtil arg1 arg2 arg3
=

arg1 =3D The production class for which you want to generate a test class
=
right from the package 	path..
      For e.g., com.smf.portfolio.PORT_Updat=
e_Portfolio 

arg2 =3D  Full  qualified path till the directory(in the spec=
ified format)
in which you want  to 	store the 	generated ".java" file.
	Fo=
r e.g., d:\\com\\smf\\portfolio etc

arg3 =3D  The name of the file what yo=
u want to give for the generated
".java" file.
	For e.g., TestPortfolio (No=
te that this is without the
extension)

and one interesting thing would be =
if you have many clsses ready and if
you want to generate the test classes(=
the skeleton) for all the classes
in the package structure that is for all =
the class files in the folder
and subfolders and put the generated class fi=
les into the same folders,
then there is one more utility "JUtilForPackage.=
java" which will do the
job for you.

The usage for this goes like this,

c=
ommond: java JUtilForPackage arg1 arg2

		arg1 =3D f:\\hari\\help\\Work_on_=
JUnit\\com
			This is the path till first folder name from
where the
			pac=
kage structure starts and from where you want
generate the
			test classes =
for all the class files in the
folders and subfolders.

       	arg2 =3D co=
m
			This should be name of the folder from where the
package
			declaratio=
n begins.

PS: ONCE IF THE TEST CLASSES ARE GENERATED THEN, IF IT IS TRIED =
TO
GENERATE AGAIN THEN IT WILL    OVERWRITE and WILL NOT APPEND. Let me
kno=
w if there is any problem in using these utilities.

Thanks and Regards
-Ha=
ri

-----Original Message-----
From: mar=
kus baumgartner [mailto:mbg@...]
Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 9:=
44 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Is there a tool which gene=
rates JUnit-test stubs?



I'm spending a lot of time passing new method in=
to the testclass and
write a
"test_" in front of it (and oftenly forget to =
do it, too).
I made a try to automate the creation of stubs for all existin=
g methods
of a
class using the Reflection API (e.g. from myProcedure(int A,=
 String B)
to
test_myProcedure_int_A_String_B. The final goal would be to h=
ave the
tool
comparing the class to the test_class and create stubs for new=
 methods
while leaving the existing ones untouched.

Before I'm going to cr=
eate it on my own, I wanted to know, if anybody
knows
about an existing too=
l, that does the job?

If it does not exist, is there a good reason, why th=
is automation
wouldn't
make sense? Sometimes for complex function you may n=
eed several
testcases,
but they can be easely created by taking the first s=
tub and append a
number...

il to:

bject to
